replies.bodyText: Indeed, please use a descriptive name here. What is this function doing? What to the numbers mean?
replies.author: skaldarnar

replies.bodyText: The values returned from the functions are assigned to float variables.Hence the cast

timeline.bodyText: Same here, please use a better name for the method.

timeline.bodyText: What constant is calculated based off the height (amount)? Is it the eye level or something like that?
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText: If function2 computes the run factor (whatever that is) you could call it getRunFactor instead.
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.message: Assigned more meaningful names and cleaned up code

timeline.bodyText:
The member height is public in CharacterMovementComponent, so there should be no need for this getter method.
See CharacterMovementComponent.java#L39
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText:
I believe 1.6f is the default height of the player? Ideally, we don't have to copy around these magic numbers and loose track of where they came from.
The best shot could be to define constants in CharacterMovementComponent which can be reused here.
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText: Height has a limitation of @Range(min = 0, max = 5) in CharacterMovementComponent, that should probably also be checked here...
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText:
The default jumpSpeed seems to be 10 (and that's the maximum at the same time o.O ). thus, I would assume that setting the player height to the default should result in the default jump speed, but substituting amount by 1.6 yiels a value ~12.4 (≠10).
This is how the jump speed is adjusted according to this function, for amount in the interval from 0 to 5:

see Wolfram Alpha
see CharacterMovementComponent.java#L53-L54
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText:
The run factor seems to be a value in the range from 0 to 10, with 1.5 being the default.
Again, calculating the new run factor with the default height of 1.6 yields a value of 1.15864 (≠1.5).
This is how the run factor scales with the given function for amount between 0 and 5. The curve looks almost linear, to be hones:

see Wolfram Alpha
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText:
The default interaction range seems to be 5 (see CharacterComponent.java#L37). With this formula the interaction range for height of 1.6 is 5.17055 (≠ 5).
This is what the plot looks like:

see Wolfram Alpha
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText: This does not take the default values, but the current values for the CharacterMovementComponent.
timeline.author: skaldarnar
skaldarnar
skaldarnar
skaldarnar

replies.bodyText: well....its just that i painstakingly constructing the other 2 functions manually,before i realized that it is much easier to arrive at them through regression,and that is how i acquired the third function.I must admit @skaldarnar you are really thorough
replies.author: godfather2

timeline.author: skaldarnar

replies.bodyText: i just looked at the restoreSpeed command. This is how it accesses default values CharacterMovementComponent moveDefault = prefab.get().getComponent(CharacterMovementComponent.class); for instance  move.jumpSpeed = moveDefault.jumpSpeed; Should i do this?
replies.author: godfather2

timeline.message: Corrected the default height and height range

timeline.author: skaldarnar

replies.bodyText: Now I saw that the values in CharacterMovementComponent are not the same as the ones in player.prefab. That should not be a problem as you are loading the default values from the prefab anyways. Thus, I would like to keep this default value as it is.
replies.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText: Ideally we'll need a lot more null checks here (for all the components). I'll refactor that part after this PR is merged, though.
timeline.author: skaldarnar
skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText:
As this is the same code as for the playerEyeHeight command I would refactor this later on to use a common
updateGazeMountPointHeight(player, amount - foreHeadSize);
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyText: If we did proper null checks this try-catch block should not be necessary (in general, catching a NPE is always a code smell as you could have done a null-check before).
timeline.author: skaldarnar
skaldarnar
